title: How to Fix a Rubbing Door

steps.headline: Check to see if the screws in the hinge plate are tight.
steps.description: Give them a little twist with a ratcheting screwdriver.

steps.headline: Lift the door by grasping both handles and gently putting upward pressure.
steps.description: Check to see if this relieves the rubbing. If it does, tighten the hinge screws with a ratcheting screwdriver. You may use a drill with a screwdriver head attachment, but you need to be careful not to overdrive the screws and break or strip them.

steps.headline: Examine the door and the doorjamb to determine where the door is rubbing.
steps.description: Look for paint that has been worn away by the door. Use a stepladder to look at the top of the door.

steps.headline: Swing the door back and forth to see if it is rubbing against the carpet or making marks on the floor.
Mark the door with a pencil at the spot that it rubs.
Remove the door from its hinges with a narrow screwdriver or awl and hammer to tap out the hinges.
steps.description: You may need someone to help you catch the door.

steps.headline: Apply masking tape to the door before cutting or sanding.
steps.description: This will help reduce the chance of the face of the door chipping.

steps.headline: Use sandpaper, a belt sander, or circular saw to remove the area where the door rubs.
steps.description: Sandpaper can be used for small rubbing problems, while the belt sander or circular saw are ideal for more extreme door-sticking issues. Be careful not to cut the door too deep or too far. Interior doors are often hollow with only 1 inch (2.54 cm) of wood to stabilize the door. Do not remove more than 1/4 to 1/2 of an inch (.64 to 1.27 cm) of wood. If your door is a solid wood door, you have more leeway in regards to how much wood you can remove.

steps.headline: Rehang the door, and check for rubbing.
steps.description: You may have to remove the door several times to keep it from rubbing; however, this is better than taking too much off.

steps.headline: Touch up the door with paint, stain, or varnish if needed.

tyn: 3 in (7.6 cm) wood or deck screws
